subject: Economics
title: Robert Shiller: Markets Are Narratives
description: A micro-lesson that makes Robert Shiller: Markets Are Narratives usable.

hook.text: Robert Shiller warned of the dot-com bubble in 2000 and the housing bubble in 2005. Both times, almost nobody listened.

buildup.text: Shiller showed that stock prices swing far more than company earnings justify. Markets are driven by emotion, not math.

discovery.text: His concept of 'narrative economics' argues that viral stories â€” not data â€” drive booms and busts in markets.

twist.text: His Case-Shiller Index tracks home prices and became the metric that measured the 2008 crash he predicted.

climax.text: Shiller proved that markets are human institutions, not computing machines. Stories move money more than spreadsheets.

punchline.text: Markets don't follow data. They follow the stories we tell about data.

quiz.question: What is Shiller's concept of 'narrative economics'?
options: Viral stories drive economic booms and busts
